number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												KICK♥♥♥♥♥GAME, DESPITE A GOD-AWFUL SAVE MODE9.5/10 Third person shooter set in Africa (the first part looks like Somalia/Black Hawk Down, the second like Temple of Doom/King Solomon's mines + a secret bioterrist lab);  a solid game full of action, scares, stress, puzzles, a hot female partner, awesome graphics, no bugs, and a story full of twists which meets all loose ends of the RE franchise (yes, Wesker APPEARS here...)My only complain is that you can't move while aiming/reloading, but other than that the gameplay is solid, and the game works like a charm with the highest settings  for 2010 (and beyond) computers, no problems with Win 8 eitherIf you loved RE4 you'll love 5, simple as that, this game is the DIRECT sequel of RE4, very, VERY similar games; the RE franchise may not be Survival Horror anymore, more like a kick♥♥♥♥♥Survival Shooter revamped franchise; anyway, you'll be scared, oh yes, by facing a horde of infected zulu warriors hell bent on killing you...with only 4 bullets left...Overall this game is the most realistic RE yet: by using a reduced inventory (only 9 items!, and that includes the medicines and ammo), it's clear that the developers want you to make decisions: more ammo or more meds? should I carry just the shotgun and bazooka? will I survive without the always reliable hand gun? will I find enough shotgun ammo? should I sacrifice the vest since I usually kill the enemies from a distance? etc etc. DECISIONS, MAN! DECISIONS! And there's the ONE BIG FLAW of this game: lack of manual save...Anyway, you can always load a saved game to collect more ammo/gold since they respawn EVERY time you just reload an autosaved game (NOTE!: the game only saves on auto, you can't manually save, AND the checkpoints DON'T reload if you quit the game; keep that in mind to avoid frustration, unless you're a noob, you should know by now that A CHECKPOINT ISN'T ALWAYS AN AUTOSAVE FILE)ANOTHER TIP: every time you quit, the game will ASK you if you wanna SAVE THE INVENTORY-> keep in mind that CHOOSING YES will save your current ammo/gold, and that CAN be a problem: for example, I reloaded a saved game with tons of ammo, but a boss kicked my♥♥♥♥♥ tired of dying-reloading-dying-reloading-dying-etc, I called t quits for the day, then I chose "yes-save the inventory" option without realizing what the hell  I was doing (I was sleepy), and the result was that the game saved my inventory with almost NO BULLETS left; I nearly had a seizure...for real; in other words, YOU SHOULD ONLY SAVE YOUR INVENTORY AFTER ADVANCING A CHAPTER OR AFTER DEFEATING A BOSS, BUT NEVER AFTER GETTING KILLED...Ignore the bitter hipster haters that still think this franchise should have ended after RE3, the RE franchise is alive and well (check out my review of RE6, that game didn't suck at all...)PD: you'll find a lot of noobs crying here because the game cannot work without GFWL; well, it's not that difficult to just SHUT DOWN the damn thing, bunch of noobs...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												Despite everyone saying this game sucks due to bad controls and others, many still say its a pretty good game. I'd have to agree with both, since the controls are not perfect for keyboard, tricky on a controler and defenetly awkward in general. They are easy to get used to, however.Story wise, this game is amazing. I've loved the story so far and i've had a lot of fun as well. Its not as fun, alone as it is with a friend, for the obvious "Trying to ♥♥♥♥ each other up" moments where you shoot an explosive barrel just to damage him a little. It has its fun moments, and co-op is always apreciated. Alone, the game gets a bit scary as it should (not enough as it should be for a horror survival game). With a friend, its fun, its good and i enjoyed it.I'm a huge resident evil fan, from 0 to 6 (i've played 0,1,2,dark side chronicles, 5 and 6. I'm trying to get resident evil 4 as its one of the best in the series. So you can see im quite a huge fan).So, in conclusion, the quality is decent, the story is good, the bosses are interesting, the final boss is also pretty cool, the co-op is fun, and even alone its decent.Overall i'd give this game a 7/10Important notes: -Worth your time if you are a resident evil fan that does play for the story and not just for the gameplay.-If you don't play for the story, not worth buying.-Bonus mission with an easter egg that allows you to play with the original camera from the first games, during that whole mission. So if you enjoyed the first games like i did, you will find this part pretty cool as well.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												GameplayIt’s better than RE4’s because there is a larger variety of enemies and a larger amount of enemies in one area. There is something bad though. El Gigante makes a return and you fight him in an on rails truck. You can’t even fight him in Mercenaries as far as I know. The RE5 fight is so easy too and felt more like a quick cameo. I’m very confused about the guns though. Some guns have special abilities. The first pistol has an upgradable ability to have headshots work as does the first shotty, but the later guns don’t have that. I guess through experimentation I will find out. There’s also some I haven’t tried like the stun rod. There is a large amount of weapons to choose from so that is good. The Mercenaries makes a comeback but no extra campaigns. It’s harder than the first one because when you pick up a new item you don’t know which item slot it will be in (you can quick select items using the number keys). So I end up not using it. (WARNING I’VE ONLY PLAYED 30 MIN OF THIS MODE SO IT MIGHT NOT BE THAT BAD).There is a big issue with this game, Sheva in single player. Sheva is smart most of the time but that is the bad part. I want to kill the enemies not her, why does she get to have all the fun. You can alleviate this by giving her a cheap pistol but sometimes when I want to shoot enemies first with the sniper she either shoots my target making me miss or alerts them by beginning to shoot before I do. She can be really stupid too. There is a part where you have to fight a bunch of lickers (very strong enemies). What triggers this even is an elevator part where only one person can go. If you go what happens is you make it (with some lickers behind you) but Sheva will run like an idiot inside the room where there is a switch instead of waiting till we kill the lickers. If Sheva goes the same thing happens. It's really funny and probably she is an intended comic relief.There is also a mod that removes Sheva from the game called ‘Alone in Africa’ but it makes her invincible and invisible to enemies and I don’t know how well it works. She probably is great to have in coop and in a harder difficulty but in Normal single player you are just babysitting her. StoryRE5 is kind of like The Amazing Spiderman. Not as good as the original (RE4 and Spiderman by Sam Raimi) and makes references. Every time Leon was talking you had a big grin at his smart talking and one liners. RE4’s story was simple: Rescue the President’s daughter. Here it’s kind of hard to understand. The evil pharmaceutical corporations (not Umbrella just piggybackers) are selling BOW samples to terrorists and rebels all over the country. Kijuju is one of them so Chris, a member of the BSAA goes to investigate with Sheva Alomar, a member of the African division of the BSAA. This is where it gets complicated for me because there is a new government in Kijuju but is that government run by terrorists? Also who is the guy who groped Sheva’s butt? Is he a Kijuju official or a member of NATO or something. And I don’t even know if they are using Uroboros or Los Plagas or both. Oh well, the villain still has the same mocking/sexual undertone in his voice so that part matches up with RE4. Also the enemies in the game are more serious (as far as I know they could be saying funny stuff in a foreign language). The enemies in RE4 were kind of comical and said things like “behind you idiot” and “I’m gonna turn you into mincemeat”. That is the only scary part of this game and the fact that the enemy is using innocent civilians and making them kill people.If you like Resident Evil 4 you should get this game. It’s bigger in terms of enemies and faster.

Posted: April 21, 2016
												Definitely not as bad as people make it seem. Doesn't have the same tone that Resident Evil 4 had (at least the first half of that game had a tight vibe) but I enjoyed it and it's goofy boss fights.Seems to have borrowed substantially from Gears of War but honestly I only have two huge gripes 1) was having to manage Sheva and her awful AI while trying not to let Chris get his face eaten. It was worse than baby sitting Ashley in RE4 because Sheva can fend for herself but she's an idiot. 2) The last boss was frustrating because I kept running out of ammo and had no way of beating it. I read some things online that said to farm gold/treasure, upgrade, get ammo but honestly even when being conservative I seemed to run out. I enabled infinite ammo to beat it, which is scummy I know, but i was at the point i just wanted to finish the game and get it over with. Never had an issue with ammo until then though, seemed to be in abundance and then the final boss takes so much punishment before he dies that no amount of ammo i could store in my inventory was a enough.

												Took a little bit of getting used to this title.  The control scheme is awkward (strafe keys become turn keys while running, can't shoot and move, can't shoot with aiming etc) which is a bit of a theme in the earlier resident evil games.  Most of the games difficulty comes from the scarcity of ammo rather than anything else.On my rig I had frequent graphical glitches which an alt-tab resolved, other than that it looks good enough.  Worth perserving with, though not exactly a scary game, more of a 3rd person shooter with zombies.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												Co-op romp'n'stomp with maximal action and lots of disgusting tentacles.----+ Fantastic co-op action experience+ Plenty of unlocks and additional content+ Graphics are excellent+ Ammo management is a real concern from start to finish+ Excellent gamepad support+/- Story is garbage, but the changing environments keep it ticking along nicely.+/- Keyboard and Mouse controls didn't feel anywhere near as good as gamepad, but YMMV.+/- Partner AI is basic but does work if you have no friends.- No local co-op- A tad repetitive----Resident Evil 5 is markedly different from all the previous games in the series in that the focus on the horror aspect is almost completely diminished. The creepy atmospheric terror of the past games is gone, but there is a different kind of violent apprehension present in this game which gives you the feeling that you definitely want to avoid dying if you can help it. Aint nobody want whatever the hell that monster is up in your junk!I first played Resident Evil 5 many years ago now in a friend's house, sitting next to him on local co-op and the experience was fantastic. So it is a bit perturbing that the PC port has the local co-op stripped out, but online co-op seems to function fine.Overall, if you are after a convincing horror game then you may want to look elsewhere but if high quality action is your thing then buying this is never going to be a bad choice. If you've got a buddy to play with then you're both in for a great time.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												This game is a joke. Its trying SO HARD to be Resi 4 in just about every way but falls falt on its own face. The characters do not have the charm of Resi 4, the enemies are either extremly forgettable or a repeated character from before, the story is so over the top and crazy that you forget what the hell you are doing, the dialogue is so forced and awkward, the entire game lacks the subtlety of Resi 4/REmake, the co-op mechanics are unbelievably forced, and the entire game is as interesting as a wet newspaper on the road. Why is this co-op? The only "co-op" parts are both players hitting switches together, throwing each other over <blank> to eventually meet up a minute later with nothing major occuring, or "sharing" each other inventory, which remarkibly is worse than Resi 4 (9 boxes, each holds a weapon/armor/ammo. an egg takes up as much space as a shotgun).Health/ammo is abundant, so the "survival" aspect to this game is thrown out the window. If you have played Resi 4, you will most likely never die, even on the hardest difficulty (except for some boss battles, as their damage feedback is so poor you have no idea if what you are doing hurts them unless the game is directly showing you with a healthbar). Enemies usually appear 10 meters in front of you and/or have a long-♥♥♥ cutscene showing you them and their weak point, completely removing any horror or tension in the air. Everything is so boring and pretictable, it feels like a terrible Hollywood blockbuster and NOT a Resi game. If Capcom wants to make an action game, go ahead! Just DO NOT slap on a Resi label.If you approach this game as a parody of Resi 4, you will get a lot more enjoyment out of it than assuming its an actual Resi game.(I have reposted this review as I got rid of a paragraph and cleaned up some points.)

content:
Posted: March 24
												I'd say that RE5 is somewhat underrated game.Sure, it's not as good as amazing RE4 was before it, but it's still a lot of fun.RE5 was a surprise when it was released, as it was fully designed for two player co-op play. This is the game's biggest strenght and weakness: RE5 is one of the best co-op games I've ever played, but as a result, it's not a very good single player experience.The game is worth buying, you would get the best experience by having a friend you can play it with, even better if you keep voice chat on.+ Great co-op+ Graphics still look nice+ The game improved the melee attack system from RE4, and it's much more fun here+ The game seems to have great performance even on a weaker PC+ Mercenaries mini game+ DLC modes are pretty good- ... but the DLC pack is overpriced- Not a good single player game (AI is dumb)- Tank controls are feeling a bit outdated at this point- Quick time events are just garbage- It's really hard to find people to play with anymore. I remember when the game was new and I played it on the PS3, and I always had many people to play with. Sadly this is no longer the case, hopefully you do have a friend who you can play with.- It seems that the game needs to install Games for Windows Live when you start it for the first time, but doesn't actually use it in-game? Seems to be some kinda leftover from the earlier days when the game actually used GFWL? (it was patched and doesn't use GFWL anymore)

Read below for "decent" review.Overall, this game is probably my favorite game of all time, like-ever. Even though it is 20 dollars, it is well worth the price.PROS:The gameplay is very good.The story is decent.Since the game is old, it runs amazing on high-end and medium-end computers.It is very fun to play alone and with a friend.It is pretty cheap, and worth the price (as I said above)CONS:You can only play with 1 other friend. I know this may not seem bad for some people, but sometimes you have a couple friends that want to play RE5 with you, and you can only play with one of them.The graphics aren't as good as some games, since it was released a long time ago.The style of the gameplay is a little hard to get used to if you play games such as Call Of Duty, or Counter Strike.Overall, I think this is a very good game, and anyone who likes action/intense/horror games should definately buy it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												Ah. Resident Evil 5. A game that to this date seems to suffer from the love-it-or-hate-it syndrome.Too bad for it, RE5 was a follow up to Capcom's most excellent (and to this day one of the best games ever made) Resident Evil 4. Let's start with a simple question: Is it as good as RE4? Hell no. But that poses another, possibly more important inquiry: Is it a good game? Hell yes.RE5 on its own is a solid, pretty (despite the gray-ish color palette) and fun experience. For its age it still holds up surprisingly well, it runs at constant 60fps even during cutscenes (which sometimes seems not to be intended causing some graphical issues) and its replay value is actually quite high. Even more so than RE4's.As far as gameplay goes it's more of the same if you played RE4. Run around, aim, shoot, explore, hit some bad guys, solve some incredibly simple puzzles (except for one particular one that actually makes you think a little bit), break boxes with your knife, get hit by a snake and run some more. Oh, and the ocassional boss fight here and there. It even adds up to the already solid gameplay with more contect-sensitive actions, like melee strings with your partner (Oh yeah, this game has an active partner) which can be very useful. Its main attractive of course is co-op, which drastically improves both the experience and replay value. Online co-op works well but as always playing with people you know is the best choice, as items, ammo and weapons are shared and that can get a bit complex when playing with randoms.Speaking of weapons and replay value, another great point for the game is its upgrading system. After you -or your partner- get a weapon you can buy it from the store, so no worries if  you missed it. Upgrading your weapons is a very effective tool to survive longer, though it costs money. You can then use those weapons on previous episodes and make your life easier, or your partner's if you are playing with a newcomer or wanna get stuff you missed. Let me tell you, replaying the first chapter is a whole different experience with an upgraded arsenal and some serious firepower.Overall this game benefits greatly from co-op and I'd dare say it makes it an actually unique experience, at least for its time. If you're one of those who skipped it because it wasn't RE4-2 or forced the co-op on you, give it a chance, I know I did and I don't regret it.

If RE 4 is God of War III, RE 5 is Marlow Briggs and the Mask of Death. Broken in all the right places.

												Resident Evil 5 is one of the most amazing games of all time. The story sets of with Chris Redfield and his new partner Sheva Alomar trying to stop biological weapons spreading in Africa. The story has a big twist from Chapter 4 and on. It becomes totally different which is a very welcoming thing. Resident Evil 5's graphics are simply stunning for a game that came out in 2009. Character models are great and so is the sound + voice acting. There is extreme fun to be had in Resident Evil 5 alone or with a friend/relative. This is definitely the best 3RD person "Survival Horror" game I've ever played. Graphics: 10/10Story: 9.5/10Sound : 9.5/10Multiplayer/Co-op: 10/10Overall: 9.7/10Resident Evil 5 is without a doubt one of my favorite games of all times. Not does it only do all thing's correct but it expands survival horror in a new genre of co-op fun.I finished this game 11 times and counting. It never gets old and there is a MASSIVE replay ability to be found. Incredible Game.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												It says I played this game for three hours, but it feels like many many more as it  is one of the most tedious games I played recently. Imagine narrow corridors disguised as alleys, narrow corridors disguised as hallways, narrow corridors disguised as sewers, narrow corridors disguised as pathways between containers and you get the idea.  Eventually we will get to narrow corridors disguised as narrow corridors.At heart most games are basically linear in concept, but this one is so obviously confined to just one narrow path that it's sucks the fun out of the game and what is more, there is virtual no story, no atmosphere , no interesting characters and no interesting dialogue to keep you going. The gameplay itself contributes to this monotonous tedium. You spent half the time scavenging for ammo which you find in small portions but need in large amounts because all the adversaries take multiple hits in the head alone.. shooting other area's of the body just make them blink or fall down for a moment, if you are lucky. And the game throws lots of them at you.Combat itself is an awkward affair. Nothing seems to work quite right. It is almost comical how the ai works.. with enemies lumbering towards you and staring past you while making threatening movements away from you. Combat is sluggish.Personally I couldn't fathom why you would want to play this game when there are some many better ones out there.If you like a game with a good story, captivating atmosphere and interesting characters, try Resident Evil Revelations 2. If, on the other hand, you like shooters, look elsewhere as well. Give Spec Ops: The Line a try.  The combat is a lot better.If you like a tedious monotonous linear game that you only play because you are a RE fan and you  are charmed by the hot side kick Sheva then buy RE 5.  But only when it's on sale.. for paying more than a few bucks for being bored is a waste of your money and your life.Anyway.. if you still want to give RE 5 a try I hope you have fun.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Heyyo, from a guy who never got into Resident Evil? RE5 is the perfect spot to jump in. The intense fighting, the importance of coop with the AI or a player... fantastic. The controls are a little hard to get used to, but they suit the game well and are actually among the best controls in a Resident Evil game after visiting other ones. The storyline is pretty good and the levels do get progressively harder and same with the enemies and the types of enemies. There is quicktime events but they're quite rare and far in between. They aren't extremely tough and punishing either which is nice. The voice acting is great and I loved the intense horror music how it put you on edge in fights and the AI for the enemies was definitely top knotch.. The coop AI? Not so much, but it still didn't ruin the experience if you were stuck in singleplayer.The graphics show off the Unreal 3 engine capabilities whilst still maintaining a great framerate. Inventory management and upgrading was a nice touch too, made replaying levels to grind for exp worthwhile and nice to try and even find secrets you missed like those special blue plate things. :P

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												The epitome of a failed turn for the franchise.RE5 continues the story of our famed original RE cast into a downward spiral that the series may not recover from.RE4 revolutionised game-play and nailed the sweet-spot for action-horror and RE5 has replicated the identical recipe which is no-longer ground-breaking.-Mediocre story.-Watered down versions of original cast ie. Wesker, Redfield, Valentine.-Same game-play mechanics as previous title.-Story is somewhat identical to previous title, but in African setting with an off-spring strain of Las-Plagas.-Co-op is certainly a PLUS to share the adventure with a friend or random online player who's seasoned with an arsenal.Do not buy if you are a fan of the survival-horror genre comprising of psychological fright, puzzles and that eerie vibes that the original franchise radiated.Capcom have learned from this mistake and fortunately, are now returning to their roots with their latest RE7 installment.

												I recommend the game. But i do NOT recommend the Steam version. Get it on console.Not my favourite RE experience, but it still has it's moments.It's a shooter, not a puzzle solver, though there are a few i guess. Anyway, not my cup of tea.And the horror aspect is as good as chemically cleansed from this particular RE title.But that does not mean that it is bad.I like it because it fleshes out parts of the RE universe and brings with it a kind of origin story to the t-virus.However, the steam version is completely broken, and probably has been for a few years now.There is a lot of negative things to say about this port, but the worst one of all.almost everytime i try to continue playing the game, my profile is gone and i suddenly have no save files.so i am forced to start the game again and again...i am pretty far into the chapters. near the end i think.but i will never be able to finish it now as my patience has run completely dry...i cannot abide this c r a p anymore. i really wish i could 3D print the .exe file in some kind of symbolic shape and then burn it. terrible, terrible port of a pretty good game in one of my favourite video games franchises.deleting the hell out of this now, never to be installed again. watching a playthrough in order to get the rest of the story, and trying RE 6...heres hoping it fares better. at the very least let me continue the game from where i left of....

RE5 isn't bad it just doesn't have enough quite enough good elements to out number the meh and is NOT worth 39.99 in 2016. I don't care if it's horror or action so long as it's fun which frankly RE5 is some good mindless fun in COOP. It's just that it's unevenly designed. I'll mostly be covering what is in this version of Resident Evil 5 which like Resident Evil 4 is constantly re-released.The PS4 got a far better version recently (In terms of features) that has an official FOV option (Not present here), an improved Mercenaries that combines Mercenaries and Reunion , retains local COOP, and No Mercy mode for the combined Mercs content. The original PC port would have been excellent had it not been for the terrible tacked on GFWL and lack of the Gold content which was previously console exclusive and added content like Desperate Escape, Lost in Nightmares and the afformentioned Mercenaries Reunion.The default FOV has always been an uphill battle for modders as every time it got fixed some small problem would arise or it wouldn't be compatible with other versions of RE5. The default FOV really didn't bother me anitially but Chris ♥♥♥♥ Boulders Redfeild is so beefy that he often obscures a lot of the screen especially if you use the unlockable gatling gun later on. Other than some design quirks that really should have been fixed after 4. The focus on COOP has led to a pretty shoddily designed singleplayer experience as there are some levels/sections that mesh quite poorly with worlds most infamous AI partner SHEVA.There's no local COOP and the mod that added it only worked on the GFWL version meaning if you don't want to deal with Sheva you need to copies or a friend who also owns Resident Evil 5 and is willing to play. Speaking of modding you will need a couple of community made patches to fix some bugs Capcom missed. At one point in the game you'll need a card key but the enemy that would drop it upon dying won't drop down meaning he can't be reached or killed and that you are stuck. That's a game breaking, progression halting bug right there and it's not the only one. Here's a link to the fixes: http://steamcommunity.com/app/21690/discussions/0/618458030688121927/I reccomend RE5 but only if you have a HUMAN partner and all the content.Here's my review of Resident Evil 4.http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/21690My review for Resident Evil 6 can be seen here:http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/221040

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												Following the footsteps of Resident Evil 4 this game is both a little better and a little worse. Still fun to play though annoying at times as it's predecessor. The story happens five years after the events in Resident Evil 4 and you play as Chris Redfield. You with your partner are sent to Africa to track down some bio-terrorist and the story goes from there. You encounter Las Plagas or some kind of it's mutation (was not really paying that much attention) that again turns people into zombie like creatures. Those are not as previously as zombies but you wouldn't tell a difference. Though would a zombie ride a bike? I think not. The story is pretty nice and takes you through a lot of well designed zones.On graphical side the game has much improved. From being dark and gray in previous title the pallet shifts to yellow and gray - thus quite nicely giving the African feel. The models are much better detailed and it's quite the step up comparing to the previous one.Gameplay has not changed all that much though there are changes. First of - they've added strafing - that helps a lot! Secondly as this game is mostly designed for co-op play you are stuck with a partner which wastes ammo, though heals you a lot making it really hard to die. It's a shame you can't play without the partner. The game structure at first really reminds of the previous game. You are thrown into the most hard part of the game within the first half an hour. At least that was my feeling.The weapon shops were removed in favour of what might be load-out menu that lets you store and buy items between levels - or when you die. The inventory system has been simplified a lot as well sadly. There are nine slots, no item stacking and arranging as previously. The weapons are pretty cool and feel nice. The electric rod however is so overpowered for regular zombies that it feels like game braking.As with previous game I did enjoy fighting zombies and doing QTEs - not so much keen on the boss fights. Though those might be a bit easier than in RE4. Still played till the end and had enough fun to recommend.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												Gave Sheeva a Shotgun with ammo and two Incendiary Grenades.Sheeva shot her Pistol until it was empty and then screamed for help.Sheeva got attacked by The Walking Ebola.10.5/10 - Would let Sheeva die again.____In all seriousness, this is when the series cemented it's interest in pursuing action set peices instead of dreadful horror set peices. They did this by giving you more outside settings during daylight and introducing a new enemy type: The J'avo. Unlike the Zombie, the J'avo is fast, resistant and can even operate weaponry - giving a whole new sort of tension to the gameplay.It kind of divided the fans a bit. All of this said, this is by no means a bad game at all. It's still got an engaging, ridiculous, over-the-top story with everyone you love and grotesque monster's to eat your flesh... but you're such a total badass by 1.5/4 into the story that I recommend playing on the highest difficulty.Online co-op functionality, no offline.New game plus upon completion - you carry over your inventory to be even more of a badass.Mercenaries available as an extra game mode.I highly recommend it as a fan of the series.* MARCH: GAMES FOR WINDOWS LIVE TO BE DROPPED AND STEAMWORKS TO BE INTEGRATED. GOLD EDITION CONTENT WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR PURCHASE, ADDING EVEN MORE CONTENT FOR A SMALL PRICE.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												I am a huge fan of the Resident Evil series and have played every game (zero-4) to completion several times.  I was at the very least disappointed with most of this game.  The partner is shoe-horned in and her AI is broken.  Survival horror gives way to frustration when you realize that Sheva's stupid AI is what's getting you killed 9 out of 10 times.  If you can play co-op it might be enjoyable, but isn't this franchise supposed to give you a sense of lonely dread?  Co-op would destroy that feeling entirely.  Also, the 9-slot inventory similar to the original games seems like a step backward from the attaché case of RE4.  Throw in the racist bits in the swamp and this game can go ♥♥♥♥ itself.There are some nice build up bits in the beginning similar to the village from RE4, but where that game took it's time before going nuts, this game just throws you into a bunch of plagas infected villagers the first chance it gets.  Even the guns feel less responsive.  Everything is just a step backwards from the masterpiece of RE4.  I bought this game since I own all the franchise and I wanted the collection to be complete, but I never thought when purchasing that I could hate a Resident Evil game this much.  I think I actually prefer 6 to this.2/10

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												First half is decent if only because it basically emulates Resident Evil 4 but with a bit more racism. The AI partner isn't very bright so you might want to play it coop.Then you get to the second half of the game when the zombies have guns and the game forces you to use poorly implemented cover shooting mechanics and everything goes downhill. The game becomes really not fun to play and a lot of the bosses are really poorly designed. At least half of them don't make it clear what you have to do, or if what you are doing is having any effect.The mercenary mode you unlock by finishing the campaign is fantastic and really fun though and is pretty much the only reason I give this game a recommendation.Oh yeah, the game uses GFWL for co-op. Not only that service is garbage but it will be taken down in July 2014. So on second though, don't buy this. Get a console version if you can.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6
												I don't understand how anyone has rated this game positivly. It's horrible in every way a game can be horrible. The AI is obnoxious, the inventory system is infuriating, the controls suck, and ammo and health are idioticly limited to the point at which I'm always starved for both, the enimies are overpowered and annoying, the plot is inane, having to split/share/manage items between two people when one of them is a useless AI moron who is always in my way is atrocious, the music is lame, the camera is never where I want it to be, and pretty much every other aspect of this game makes me want to throw my computer out a window and swear off technology. I've played every Resident Evil game multiple times through, some in the double-digets, and this is the single entry in the franchise that I just can not force my way all the way through regardless of how many times I reinstall and reattmpet it. It's just trash. Plain and simple. At this point, I'm done trying - after having it blow through all the health and ammo I purchased/collected killing a bunch of hunters, and then throwing me directly into a boss fight with Wesker when I have no items, I'm done trying to get to the end of this nonsense. I'm uninstalling it for the final time and watching the rest as a playthrough on YouTube. This game just doesn't have enough redeeming qualities to make it worth the constant failures it makes at every turn. Honestly go play any other Resident Evil game; they're all better than this one.

												what did i like about this game:1.) sheva's cute2.) looks pretty good once you remove the♥♥♥♥♥♥filterwhat did i not like about this game:1.) co-op is mandatory since the AI is a useless boat anchor that will burn all your ammo and then die2.) enemies are either brain-dead nonthreats or brain-dead giant piles of hitpoints that have obnoxious instakill attacks3.) inventory is tiny and managing it is a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥br>4.) mechanics designers and level designers seemed to have some kind of fundamental disagreement on what sort of game they were making and as a result you have shooter maps while your characters walk really slow, can't move while aiming and have limited ammo5.) bosses and large enemies have too much health6.) bosses and large enemies have way too much health7.) bosses and large enemies just have an obnoxious amount of health, seriously, what were they thinking8.) why does one of the enemy models look like borat, what part of africa is this supposed to be

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												I'm so confused as to how no one hates the insane, wonky mouse sensetivity.  It's moves painfully slow left and right and up and down flies everywhere at the slightest heavy breath.How?  how can the controls be so bad?  I've tried it on 4 different computers, there's no lag, the sensitivity is just insane and the aiming is slow and terrible.I just got done playing Resident Evil Revaltations and it was the best RE experience I've had since Code Veronica (my favorite game of the series, I love 4 as well though and liking RE: Revalations shows I dont' have a problem with the concept of the game itself)Just...I'm so blown away.  What's wrong with me that I have this problem and no one else seems to? lolNo one else has a problem with these controls?  They're slow and clunky and are too sensitive in one direction and and slow in another.I'm so sad, I want to enjoy it, but the controls are♥♥♥♥♥♥after playing other PC ports.THEN there's this weird item system and the partner thing. Why?  Why do this? Why?  Why? Why?

Posted: October 29, 2015
												This game ranks solidly in the top 5 worst games I've ever played, or attempted to play, I should say. The broken and unfixable movement controls alone were enough to make the game unplayable. And that's without even considering the bugs, horrible level design, camera issues, gated enemies, QTEs, etc. etc. etc.I honestly can't understand how anyone liked this game on PC, let alone enough people to net a "very positive" rating over all of the poor reviews. But regardless, I feel completely cheated out of my money after the reviews here and metacritic.This will definitely be the last RE game I ever buy.

content:
Posted: February 26
												It'd be a great game... if it worked. Unfortunately it demands a games for windows live account, nevermind the fact games for windows live was shut down years ago. I clicked on the GFWL link that pops up and it takes me to XBox login, which I don't have because I've never had an XBox live account. I could've made one, but it would've required giving microsoft ALL my contact data AND free access to my EMail account. Even if you do manage to start the game (Which requires fan-made patches) it doesn't save your progress. That means every time you exit active play, boom. Back to the beginning with no unlocks, no gear, no anything. If they ever fix it I'll give it a thumb's up. Until it's playable however, huge thumb's down.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												I've played this game on playstation and xbox each, and loved the experience.  The game itself is fine.  However, the steam version will not allow anyone to actually play the game with a partner, which is (let's face it) the only fun way to play these modern Resident Evil games.  This is because of a temporary agreement that fell through, where xbox-live users would be able to get a new Steam-only "live" account for a fee.  However, the site has long since been taken down, and with it went the ability to play the bundle of games they supported for the direct port.  Because of this, I recommend picking up Resident Evil 6 instead and having fun with a friend of yours.  It's the best co-op experience I've had.  However, this version of Resident Evil 5 is unplayable, as far as I'm concerned.  Please steer clear, from one long-time Resident Evil fan to (hopefully) another.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												This game just did not satisfy me the way I was expecting.  It's not a bad game, and relatively easy especially if you are not good at shooters.  There is a lot of action, and in the end that was what kept me going until I finished the game. A few good bosses, most not very difficult.  There are points in the game when you are scared - just a few, though.  That was my biggest complaint.  I went in expecting a frightening experience and what I got was much like the movies - an over the top action adventure.  So, then I considered it as an action game...and I could not find much merit there as it was just slow.  Really slow.  Granted, it's meant to be.  Just that it niether satisfied me to be a slow horror game or a fast action game.  I wish the action was a bit faster so that I would get more excited rather than "ho hum, more zombie baddies to shoot".  More than a few levels were a grind.  The ending was okay - typical of an action game.  My advice is if you want scary, don't look here.  If like B- action movies, then you'll find it mildly entertainng. And good luck with GWFL until Capcom removes it.  I got it on discount awhile back and glad I didn't spend more than $5 for it.  Co-op is more fun, but I played it single player.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												I'm trying to be nice about this review but I'm sorry I have to be honest and say this game is horrible for a Resident Evil title. I couldn't even stand the first 20 minutes without taking a break. First off, it's not Resident Evil. It's some game that was originally about gangs and cannibals in Africa and they snatched it up and tweeked it and slapped the name on the box. The more you play the more obvious it becomes. There are so many situations where you "use cover" and it really feels like a light gun game on rails. It's not Resident Evil, it's Shooting Gallery starring Resident Evil characters. If you hate zombies, you're in luck because you won't find a single one in the entire game. Lame.I want to start by saying I really hate hate Quick Time Events and even if you know what buttons to press half the time the game doesn't pick up on your input properly. If you like QTEs and dying instantly for no reason other than to die and restart at the same QTE again, well, it's your lucky day. This title is chock full of QTEs and they really would be unecessary if the game was structured better. If you're expecting that good old inventory management feel that revolves around ammo management and semi-survival, forget it. This game has a million bazillion weapons and ammo/health everywhere. Then to make it worse in several places they stick you on a turret with infinite ammo. You already had infinite ammo/weapons a shop to buy stuff every five seconds and now you're on a turret with infinite machine gun bullets and rockets? Wtf? I don't know why sticking a player on a turret is so freaking popular in videos games these days but it's really overplayed. This game has an identity crisis that falls somewhere between Halo, Tomb Raider and Call of Duty and it really doesn't work.The difficulty is easy and the graphics while dated for 2015 aren't too bad aside from some of the 3D models that look outright horrible, ie. the zombie dogs. Progression is very linear and sadly you won't familiarize yourself with areas or double back at all. You won't have your nice little storage box. You won't have fancy keys or items you build, you won't be solving puzzles. Do you remember progressing through areas with eerie well made environments and great ambience where each new room was unsettling or suspenseful? Digging up journals and finding bits of manuscript that creepily progress the storyline? Forget it, none of that here, you'll get a taste of it toward the end of the game but mostly you'll be running around like Modern Warfare with infinite revives PEW PEW! It just disgusts me.The camera movement in this game gives me a headache. The camera movement speed is inconsistent when standing still compared to when moving and it's headache inducing. The quick menus for inventory management are nice but they are incomplete. I actually like the old pause menus in the originals and I understand eliminating them can create suspense but since there's little danger or scare factor there's no point. You can split stacks in the item menu but you can't do it efficiently, so you end up playing with a stack of 20 grenades instead of two. Why restrict inventory management like this? It doesn't make sense to do that because allowing the player to split item stacks exactly how they want has absolutely no negative impact on the challenge and having an inventory system that's advanced while neglecting completed features only frustrates the player.Resident Evil games have always utilized the melee weapon as a huge factor in both survivability and ammunition management. Using melee to conserve ammo while gambling a risked close encounter and possible exchange on hp recovery items is essential to generating part of the fear and suspense that all good early RE games had. Unfortunately in this release it's thrown out the window completely. You don't need to conserve ammo so it doesn't even matter. There's a basic karate combo system that enhances immersion but that's not Resident Evil. Something about shooting everything once then punching it across the room like Kazuya from Tekken is out of place.What's singleplayer? Chris said it best in game, "partner?" Oh yes that's right they stick an AI team mate up your @** the entire game. She constantly walks in front of you, combines green herbs, jams ammo into your inventory and constantly breathes heavily for no reason. You never feel alone or stranded with such unnecessary company. That trademark sense of despair that always floursihed in RE games is gone. Even the great feeling you had when you encountered an NPC in the older games was ruined because there's no solo progression. Your trusty partner is always there chatting it up and getting in the way. Sometimes she's helpful but most of the time she's just kind of there and if the partner dies you lose and start over. Why?! Let me play singleplayer as singleplayer and co-op as co-op. This game nearly drove me to tears it's so bad and then you have to deal with this.What's sad is the overall feel of the game. One half feels like a reasonable attempt at the continuation of the saga and the other half feels like some completely different game mashed into one another. You press start and you're going straight from point A to point B with a load screen shop. There is little exploring, zero backtracking areas with new monsters, and not one dang typewriter/sanctuary room. Other games in the series are linear but you are dropped into a semi-open world and are left to explore and find keys, events, puzzles and bosses with a little room for discovery. There's a DLC pack called "Lost in Nightmares" that is a seperate quest that looks to be more like the original RE format and playstyle, I have yet to try it out, but it's probably better than the main game.I kept thinking my opinion would change the further I progressed but it was only confirmed. The voice acting is good the graphics are pretty and some of the bosses are cool but the basic synopsis is simple. You're Chris Redfield, you're in Africa, and it sucks. You click start, Chris yells in the hand radio, "Come in HQ" text is displayed on the screen "This device has no power" he looks at his partners chest, there's a Quick Time Event, the end credits roll. Congratulations you just beat Resident Evil 5, I saved you the struggle. If you do decide to endure this misery I can say that the one thing you might have to look forward to is cleavage and side-boob. Every time you go through a door Chris will spin around and look right at his partner's sweater puppies. Being that this is a mature title and there's been practical nudity in previous titles, mainly Code Veronica, you can be comforted in knowing that this title will fall short leaving you only a fading memory of Chris Redfield's beard stubble and beautifully rendered sideboob.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Resident Evil/Biohazard has been a beloved zombie shooter for many years now. However, despite the praise of its atmosphere and gameplay, the game was regularly criticized for its clunky movement controls and unintuitive U.I. Resident Evil needed to evolve and rework these dated issues if it wanted to survive its own longetivity. In 2005, RE4 hit the market with overwhelming positive reviews. It pioneered the over the shoulder view of shooters, delivering superb gameplay, action, and smooth UI/controls. The community's only issue was they wanted to play the thriller with a friend. Capcom heard the plight and RE5 was announced. We were all ready to pounce on the idea that we could finally RE in co-op....however, we learned the hard way that we might have jumped the shark, as well as received another punishing lesson on "Why we don't pre-order games."Plot 4/10In typical RE fasion, the story is bumpy, confusing, littered with holes, and told from the perspective of a 10 yr old that was along for the ride. It's everything you've seen before: the (insert random letter)-virus has broken out this time because - dammit we're not out of letters in the English alphabet yet - and it's turning people into...zombies. Capcom has left their mark on abysmal story telling once more, giving you - once AGAIN - JUST enough of an excuse to slaughter everything in your path from point A to point B, taking brief intermissions to hunt down keys (at least it doesn't happen in a castle this time). So, the formula is: country/location + random letter in the English alphabet + "virus" = RE story. Most of the cast sound like they said their lines on the first take with no director telling them "sound more like this". Every character is one-dimensional with dialogue that is even worse. "What is this place? Where is Jill? What the hell is that?! We need a key." is the plot in a nutshell. Hell, THE WIKI tells the story better than this game does! It's pathetic. I gave it a 4 because Chris does have ONE moment of personality that made his character acceptable. Sound 5/10The sounds are all great! Guns, groans, motors, stone slabs moving around, splashing water, and even "some" of the actors are impressive! (I was most impressed with Jill's voice. She was terrific! Wesker is passible too.) The low score comes from the rest of the cast. Their lines are delivered with all the excitement and enthusiasm of a business math teacher. Combine this with the terrible plot/dialogue, you will be skipping every cutscene with no regrets. Capcom's only desparate attempt to keep the player interested in the cutscenes is showing a chick half-nude. "Hi, I'm (name) and my purpose in this plot is.....is um.....it's....uh I don't have one....um BOOBIES!" Does Capcom hate women or what? The music is awesome! Some of the scores are on par with John Williams' compositions!


YouTube™ Video: Resident Evil 5 Original Soundtrack - 17 - An Emergency (Digital Ver) 

			Views: 41,323		

			Biohazard 5 OST - 17 - An Emergency (Digital Ver)		

Graphics 7/10I think they're beautiful, but almost everyone disagrees with me. My only gripe with the graphics is the enviornments are so bland; brown/tan washouts with no memorable scenery. They look great, but are just uninteresting.Gameplay 8/10Who cares about all that stuff anyway? It's a game, right? So, how's the game play? It works rather well! The controls are almost identical to RE4, which is fine and all, but nothing noteworthy or "all that new" was added aside from minor things. The game plays like RE4.5 instead of RE5. You use the same guns, fight the same guys, use the same controls, but this time, we tossed in Africa to the above mentioned formula. One new thing I loved was the ability to combo each other's melee attacks; tossing an enemy back and forth to your teammate, or getting behind a stunned enemy to kill it instantly. You can upgrade your guns and there's a few new toys like the shock stick that are kinda fun (but very under powered). Another feature is the new inventory and how it allows you to switch weapons on the fly or trade with your teammate. Although co-op, the game never takes advantage of the idea of having 2 players. The only time you "cooperate" is: I stand here 'n kill stuff, you go ober dere 'n kill stuff. I also hate the QTE's. They never give you enough of a warning, and usually are just a free death. It doesn't happen often, but when it does, it feels cheap and hurts the fun factor. In the end, RE5 is fun, and co-op will sate, but you can't shake that feeling that it's half-hearted. (RE5 got a lot of flak for its slow moving characters and sluggish turning. I personally think it's wonderful, and RE should have kept this. When they added free movement of other third-person games, the series went straight to CoD/GoW. I blame most of RE6's failure on this alone. Controls take some getting used to, but you'll learn to embrace it.)Side notes: I wanted to save extra room to address the game's most controversial topic: racism. The short answer: ludacris. A virus breaks out all over the world in different games, but when it lands in Africia, NOW its racist? So, I can shoot zombies, but if I see a black zombie, now it's unethical. It doesn't make sense. "Racism" is very poorly defined nowadays, and everyone's just jumping in the bandwagon of ERMAHGERD RATHITH everytime a black person is even involved in said topic. Capcom even apologized to the world saying "we learned our lesson: no more racism!" As soon as I heard that, I knew 1 of 2 things were going to happen: either the next RE would happen in Asia (because Capcom is Japanese. It's politically safe.) or we would go back to Europe in RE4 where we killed 1,000s of hispanics, because obviously the community finds that more ethical. Sure enough, RE6 took place in Asia. Hire me. SHEVA'S DIALOGUE FLAT OUT SAYS WHY SHE EXISTS. Not because of character design, not to satisfy a plot hole in the story, but to ease the tensions of a white American killing black zombies...and a souless player-slot. I'm against racism and all, but this whole "racism" fad has derailed and spiraled out of control. Look at this this way for a second: we say this game is racist because its a white male killing blacks. Well, what if it was a black male killing white female zombies? Would that be acceptable? Why or why not? How about attacking the game for a REAL issue of bigotry like it's portrayal of women? I think the boss fight against Jill deserves some criticism. Kill 1,000's of hispanic zombies in RE4, nobody bats an eye. Kill a few black zombies, and everyone loses their s*&%.A final thing I have to address is the "Gold Edition". Never heard of it? That's because it was a CONSOLE-ONLY RELEASE. After seeing some videos of GE's content, I found that it was had enough extra content to be a whole sequal in itself; as if Capcom deliberately witheld half of the game to release it later (not the first or last time they've done this. Check out Marvel vs. Capcom 3 then Ultimate MvC3). PC fans of RE5 were left in the dust. A nice, big, middle-finger was shot to PC gamers which is another of Capcom's terrible blights on their reputation (google metacritic Chaos Legion).The VerdictRE5 does deliver on fun gameplay, but coop is never taken to the height that it deserves. Unlockables do add noteworth replayability, but poor acting, poor story telling, bad plot, actors reluctant to do their jobs, and boring characters will ensure you don't stay for the story. RE5 scores a 7/10. It's a good game and worth buying, even for a solo play, but it's far from great; worth a run though.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												I bought this last year for the Halloween Sale and it was like 5 dollars.  It wasn't even worth 5 dollars...This game is nothing more than a console port of a really bad console game.  The needless button mashing will aggravate you, the unnecessary 6 second long cutscenes which poorly attempt to weave together a plot that you can't really care about will annoy you, the main characters are apparently mentally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥,  and the feeble attempt by Capcom to connect this to previous Resident Evil games by inserting little notes, objects, and green and red herbs doesn't really make it a Resident Evil game. The over the shoulder view blocks half your screen and you can't change it, the combat system attempts to emulate something like call of duty except the weapon manipulation is dependant on an RE inventory system which makes no sense at all.  Also, there's a box with a thing in it that you can not pick up (glitch?) and Chris has a huge knife on his back that you desperately need to use but somehow cannot select out of inventory and there apparently is no melee feature, it only prompts you to button mash at random intervals.  You're immediately overwhelmed by multiple clone zombies and run out of ammo, need to keep moving and looking for pathways, yet half the screen is blocked by your character, and the rest of the time your sidekick is blocking your way and asking for help because they're apparently incompetent.  It's time for Capcom to just put this franchise in a coffin and bury it for good.

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												The year was...well, I don't exactly remember what year this game came out, actually, but it was a long time ago. I picked it up back in 2011 when I, as yet, didn't have internet access, and it was my first major experience with GFWL. Honestly, I have to say the service was my only favorable memory of this horrible game, since unlike Valve's Steam service, it didn't require an internet connection to do everything. I never even had to register the used copy of the game I bought (try doing that now, I dare you).Still, we're here to discuss Resident Evil 5 not bash Steam (and trust me, this is a topic I can discuss at length).The good:Voice acting: Like in the previous title, Re5's voice acting is incredibly solid. This has been on an upward trend since Code Veronica, despite the slight detour they took with Zero, and I'm honestly happy with it.Music: Say what you will about the game, but Re5 has some of the best musical cues in the series. The themes during most of the boss fights are especially memorable; Wesker's is probably the best.Graphics: Even five years later, Resident Evil 5 is still a great looking game...and therein lies the problem.The Bad:Controls: The PC controls are simply unusable, except for the standard grapple break prompt, which is broken in the other direction (the average AD prompt takes about three seconds to break out of). The inventory is completely unusable (and doesn't even work correctly in Mercenaries Reunion, or so I've heard). This remains the only game I own I've never played start to finish with a mouse and keyboard. Buy yourself a gamepad if you intend to play this; you'll need it.Mechanics: Probably my "favorite" two are the idiotic real-time inventory and Dying Status. The inventory system in Resident Evil 4 was perfect, so naturally Capcom went and broke it in the sequel. You can't move and shoot, or even move and heal, and enemies have absolutely no compunctions against beating you to death while trying to mix herbs or reload your guns. You've also got maybe a third as much space to play with, which cannot be upgraded, and half your inventory can walk away, in the form of your AI partner, who has to be next to you in order to trade items. While this makes logical sense, I still found myself missing the system from the last game.Dying Status is probably the game's most frustrating addition. Whenever your character absorbs enough punishment, they'll enter a state wherein they can no longer fight back and must be rescued by your partner. While its concept is similar to Last Stand from Call of Duty, Dying manages to be about a million times more frustrating. You can barely move and can't fight back, but enemies can still attack you, and you can even be grappled into Dying by some enemies, which is almost always fatal. In Mercenaries, you have the option to revive yourself by spamming the B button, but again the same camping comes into play; I was once put into Dying three times within a minute by the same enemy hovering behind me and smacking me with his axe before I got frustrated and rage quit. This brings me to my third complaint, QTEs. Despite what people say, these have always been present to some degree in every Resident Evil game to date, though they first became more obvious in the more action centric Re4. The dodge sequences from that game were probably my least favorite, so naturally Capcom adds even more in, and then some. We still have a boss fight consisting entirely of QTEs, though this time it's closer to the end of the game, which isn't as bad. However, fighting Wesker in both the main game and "Lost in Nightmares" is almost exclusively a QTE fest, which is compounded further by the game's irritating habit of not registering your button presses or simply not giving you the prompt. Another especially notorious sequence involves Chris punching a boulder; despite hitting every single prompt correctly, Chris still gave up on this three times during one playthrough.Of course, being a failure as a game wouldn't be so bad if Re5 at least had an enjoyable plot, but sadly this isn't the case either. Since I'm not worried about spoiling a five year old game, I'll go ahead and lay things out for you:Jill has apparently been killed at some point earlier on, except Chris doesn't seem to attach any significance to her death, since prior to the game actually starting he apparently learned she was still alive. Considering losing his best friend the way he apparently did should be the defining character moment for him, it seems odd that just about everything Chris went through is offscreen, compounded further by his lack of development. It's hard to become invested in Chris, since he doesn't seem to have much of a personality.Sheva Alomar gets a lot of hate, but honestly I didn't mind her. Her AI is only as dumb as the human player alongside her; if you're lazy and expect her to play the game for you, you'll be disappointed, but if you take into account her limitations, she's a quantom leap ahead of your last partner, Bill "Can't Reload His Own Guns" Coen. Still, while Sheva is never unlikable she never has the breakthrough characterization Helena Harper got in the sequel, so she's also kind of dull. All the mildly racist fan service she's put through doesn't help matters, either.There are other problems, too. It's heavily implied by the events at the beginning of the game the BSAA are somehow in league with Tricell, but this subplot falls off the boat and is never fished back out. For that matter, Chris doesn't seem to much care for the organization he canonically helped found and no one really seems to respect him; Jill Valentine, meanwhile, is treated like a rock star by every operator she meets, and no one once expresses shock that she's not dead.Tricell, a company similar to Umbrella but not actually them at all (in the sense they seem to have done sod-all before this point in the series) is the main antagonist of the game...we're led to believe. Their president, Excella Gione, has apparently been bribing Ricardo Irving (the game's one memorable villain) to release bioweapons in Africa. Why she's doing this is never explained, anymore than the presence of the Plagas from the previous game, since both ensure the BSAA get involved and ultimately ruin everything, but hey, if not for this we wouldn't have a game, right?It's not especially clear how giving Irving money was enough for him to willingly transform into a sea monster, either, since there's now no way for him to spend this money. Granted, when you consider this is a game which ends with Chris punching a boulder during the final confrontation with Wesker in an active volcano I suppose logic is something in short supply.Since this is now a pure shooter, I guess we can't not mention the guns. Re5 does have a pleasing assortment...except they're pretty much identical to the ones from Re4. The Beretta 92FS (called the M92F for some idiotic reason) is roughly comprable to the Silver Ghost, the P8 is the FiveseveN, the Sako 75 is the Springfield, the PSG-1 is the SL8...This is, of course, without the four guns which are carried over from the previous game and fill the exact same roles (the M3 is the best shotgun in the game, the RPG is the "Screw this boss fight" weapon). The handguns feel the most useless, since you're only given one (well, one for each of you) for free, and there's no reason to buy more. Equally worthless are the "machine gun" (read: automatic weapons) class, which are hilariously inaccurate and underpowered to a fault (shot for shot, the Beretta does something like five times the damage of the AK-74, and by the end of the game has a higher capacity to boot!). Also, Steam will delete all your achievements if you import your save.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												RE5 is the second worst RE game Capcom ever made.Having said that, it's still pretty fun. You have never known the agony of defeat until you have played this game on splitscreen co op on Professional with a partner who has all guns maxed and you have nothing. Only dying 60 times per chapter due to QTE fails and stupid design will temper your skills in the fire of RE5. So, yes, it's fun.It's also even worse than RE4 at being a Resident Evil game. Granted, it does  have an actual lab, but no virus, and it does have Wesker and Chris and Jill. Wesker is Neo now by the way, and the story is over the top stupid though so it does qualify as an RE game in that regard.There's just nothing scary about this game, at all. Barring a horde of hundreds of lickers, nothing in this game produced tension. The environments are all painfully well lit; the enemies predictable; weapons upgradable; you can melee everything to death, too. Really the only good thing they included in this game mechanics wise was a very limited 9 slot inventory system.If we're lucky, they will include RE5 gold content for free with this Steamworks update. Gold had Mecenaries reunion - co op mercs and it was awesome, with oldschool RE characters in it. It also has Lost in Nightmares which, compared, to RE5 is a real survival  horror game, and Desperate Escape which shows Jill's part of the game after you find her.Despite it's downsides, it's still a decent third person shooter and a good co op game. At least it's not RE6.Edit * LOL they are trying to charge 15 dollars for 5 year old DLC as if the people playing on PC don't own the game elsewhere.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												Harry Potter is a series of fantasy novels written by British author J. K. Rowling. The novels chronicle the life of a young wizard, Harry Potter, and his friends Hermione Granger and Ron Weasley, all of whom are students at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry . The main story arc concerns Harry's struggle against Lord Voldemort, a dark wizard who intends to become immortal, overthrow the wizard governing body known as the Ministry of Magic, and subjugate all wizards and Muggles.Since the release of the first novel, Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, on 26 June 1997, the books have found immense popularity, critical acclaim and commercial success worldwide. They have attracted a wide adult audience as well as younger readers, and are often considered cornerstones of modern young adult literature.[3] The series has also had its share of criticism, including concern about the increasingly dark tone as the series progressed, as well as the often gruesome and graphic violence it depicts. As of July 2013, the books have sold more than 450 million copies worldwide, making them the best-selling book series in history, and have been translated into seventy-three languages.[4][5] The last four books consecutively set records as the fastest-selling books in history, with the final instalment selling roughly eleven million copies in the United States within twenty-four hours of its release.The series was originally published in English by two major publishers, Bloomsbury in the United Kingdom and Scholastic Press in the United States. A play, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, based on a story by Rowling, premiered in London on 30 July 2016 at the Palace Theatre, and its script was published by Little, Brown as the eighth book in the series.[6] The original seven books were adapted into an eight-part film series by Warner Bros. Pictures, which has become the second highest-grossing film series of all time as of August 2015. The franchise has also generated much tie-in merchandise, making the Harry Potter brand worth in excess of $15 billion.[7]A series of many genres, including fantasy, drama, coming of age and the British school story (which includes elements of mystery, thriller, adventure, horror and romance), the world of Harry Potter explores numerous themes and includes many cultural meanings and references.[8] According to Rowling, the main theme is death.[9] Other major themes in the series include prejudice, corruption, and madness.[10]The success of the books and films has ensured that the Harry Potter franchise continues to expand, with numerous derivative works, a travelling exhibition that premiered in Chicago in 2009, a studio tour in London that opened in 2012, a digital platform on which J.K. Rowling updates the series with new information and insight, and a trilogy of spin-off films premiering in November 2016, among many other developments. Most recently, themed attractions, collectively known as The Wizarding World of Harry Potter, have been built at several Universal Parks & Resorts amusement parks around the world.

number of helpful: 4 of 17 people (24%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												While the game is somewhat enjoyable in terms of story, there are a few things that completely kills it. Not being able to move while shoting or reloading is one of them,. While this is something I can live with, thoese quick time events are really frustrating, especially during boss fights. They can change up the sequence, and you have a millisecond to react, which really kills the game. Speaking of which, the boss fights are really annoying. They are either extremely easy or extremely hard, depending on how fast you figure out what you are supposed to do and whether or not you will be resupplied with ammo. And the final two boss' where some of the most infuriating ones I have ever played. Not only do you have to figure out what to do via trial and error, they are simply unforgiven. First one can kill you with two shots flat, so better bring lots of healing items. The last one is just infurating and if you dont know what to do going in to it, you will be basically out of luck.The store is another point of frustration, while it works fairly OK. You can buy all weapons, but you will find most of them in the game regardless. As the game is fairly stingy with ammo, you are better off limiting what weapons you keep on you anyway. But the most annoying part is that you cannot buy either ammo or grenades in the store, making a boss fight you forgot to save up bullets for or went in to with few resources almost impossible as you have to be extremely accurate with the way you do things. Overall, I would not recommend this game, it can be fun, if you play co op, but in the end it was so furiating I just beat it out of spite. More than once I had to check a strategy guide just to figure out how to deal with a boss, simply because you will not get a single indication in game if you are doing things right. Only redeeming quality of the game is the coop, in which it can be fairly entertaining at times, but overall I feel the frustration it puts you through greatly outweighs the fun you can have.

												From the ashes of old conflicts, a new terror arises. The Umbrella Corporation and its crop of lethal viruses have been destroyed and contained. But a new, more dangerous threat has emerged. Years after surviving the events in Raccoon City, Chris Redfield has been fighting the scourge of bio-organic weapons all over the world. Now a member of the Bio-terrorism Security Assessment Alliance (B.S.A.A.), Chris is sent to Africa to investigate a biological agent that is transforming the populace into aggressive and disturbing creatures. Joined by another local BSSA agent, Sheva Alomar, the two must work together to solve the truth behind the disturbing turn of events. Featuring a revolutionary new co-op mode of gameplay, Resident Evil 5 will let players experience fear together as terror moves out of the shadows and into the light of day.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												One of my favorite games to date, and it runs fantastic on DX10. Its frantic real-time item management and tank controls offer a learning curve for the typical third-person shooter player, while leaving a wide enough gap for brand new players to learn and adapt through the campaign. Co-op is rewarding, with an inventory sharing-system, occasional branching paths and even voice commands for gamers who don't want to use a mic. Mercenaries is extremely addicting, and with the formerly console-exclusive DLC finally available, I highly recommend this game for anyone.Some will give the game a negative review because it's so unlike the earlier games in the series with its OTS camera and emphasis on shooting action, which is a fair assessment, but if you come into RE5 without a predetermined expectation of what a "Resident Evil" title is supposed to be, I'd say it's one of the best of its generation of AAA titles. Clean, beautiful, optimized and just plain fun to play. Plus the combination of top-tier voice actors and bottom-tier writing makes the cutscenes worth watching again on every playthrough.Note: I have far more hours on record  than my Steam account shows, as I originally played the game since 2009 on my GFWL account. Between GFWL and Xbox, I've likely logged about 900+ hrs. Like I said, love this game.

												Definitely recommended with a partner. You only get to carry 9 different items. Just nine. Armor and a better melee weapon? Takes up a slot. Find a new gun? Hope you have a slot open. Have a single green herb and found a red one and you want to combine but your inventory is full? Too bad.The game is a bit deceptively difficult, but rather fun if you know what you're doing. Lots of treasures strewn about, and plenty of things to shoot at. It's only the second RE game I've played, after Revelations. If you're used to the newer RE games, this will need some getting used to. Similar to RE4 considering its success, if you liked 4, you'll probably like 5 as well.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												Fantastic graphics, even to this day in 2015. It's also my favorite modern Resident Evil game. They really fleshed out the melee system to where you can dominate baddies with head stomps and massive Chris bicep punches. The weapon leveling system is really fun and you can take the leveled weapons to the next playthrough so you'll be a god by the time you're done. It's also one of my favorite co-op experiences. GIMME AN EGG

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												Resident Evil 5 is a 3rd person action-survival horror game that focuses more on the action a little more than the horror when compared to the earlier Resident Evil games. Therefore, this game is shunned by many fans and players alike. Yet the game itself still manages to keep up a similar level of gameplay to a ealier game in the series, Resident Evil 4. In the game, you play as two B.S.A.A. (Bioterrorism Security Assessment Alliance) agents sent in to investigate a terrorist threat in Kijuju (A fictional part of Africa). Those agents are Chris Redfield, a protagonist to the first Resident Evil game, and Sheva Alomar, a replacement partner for Chris after his earlier partner, Jill Valentine, pasted away. The gameplay is incredibly similar to Resident Evil 4, but has a few change ups. First, and the most noticable, is the game's main co-operative gameplay. Second, the inventory system limits you to only 9 inventory slots instead of the briefcases in the earlier games. And lastly, the larger crowds of enemies. Although the game loses a lot of focus with the "surivor horror" section, it makes up for it's clever gameplay and it's interesting and more plot twisting story. All in all, the game is fun, but is better when playing with a friend (Which is not necessary).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												I have only played the co-op mode of this game, and only intend to do that. For someone who is terrified of anything remotely scary, I find this game surprisingly enjoyable, partly because the co-op mode is very well thought out, not just thrown in at the last minute. This is the only Resident Evil game I've played to date, but I don't feel like I'm missing too much. I could understand the story, and find it totally immersive. The graphics is great, and the environments, as well as the enemies you fight, are varied, and doesn't feel too repetitive. I also like how it feels like a genuine survivor game. You can't buy ammo. There's ammo to pick up, but only a few bullets at a time. It really makes you treasure every shot. It's incredibly satisfying when you kill something too, unlike in L4D2, where you don't really realise you have killed anything. This game almost TELLS you the thing you've been shooting at is dead. This is important for me, as it is what I often look for in games which require killing; that satisfying last shot, or last hit is utmost rewarding. You can upgrade your guns which I very much enjoy, and once you have beaten the game, there are a lot of little secrets for you to discover. That I like very much. However, there is something about this game that I very much dislike. The control system. It feels like, although it might not be true, that it has been directly ported to PC from consoles, so the controls just feel very controller-like. When you want to turn, you turn extremely slowly for about 1 full second, then very very quickly, so you're back to facing the thing you wanted to turn away from. This is particularly annoying when you're next to an enemy with a chainsaw lifted high above your head. Of course, there is the quick turn button, though that just doesn't give you the control you have with a mouse. I am slowly getting accustomed to it, but then I've already had about 8 hrs with the game. Overall though, there is a lot to like about this game. I just wish they would make the controls more keyboard + mouse friendly.
