number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
Resident Evil has always been a franchise of a strong story, and an even stronger atmosphere. As a fan of the series since the first game, I find these two elements to be infinitely important in making an entry in the series feel relevant. I found Resident Evil 5 to fail in accomplishing that in so many different ways that I don't know where to start.First, I'd like to point out that this isn't a terrible game through-and-through. It has some good moments and its general gameplay is fairly enjoyable, but it's not a great game either. Second, as another disclaimer, I am aware that this game wasn't supposed to follow in the footsteps of the classic games, and the gameplay was already overhauled by Resident Evil 4, so that can't be held against this title. However, Resident Evil 4 was a great game, even if it too distanced itself from its predecessors. It had some major flaws as well, but it was infinitely better than Resident Evil 5.Starting with the better qualities of this game, it's actually relatively fluent and enjoyable to play: the controls work fine and it's fun to shoot things. It also looks good, and just by playing it for a while doesn't invoke that much to complain about.However, after a while the gameplay becomes grinding, and things like the camera angle start to chafe - you will find yourself spitting profanities in frustration as it becomes impossible to react in time or estimate distances correctly because of the camera, and enemies that move in unexpected ways behind the character model. This is a part of the game, granted, but it doesn't add much to the enjoyment. Save for the clumsiness with the camera and sometimes the controls, the difficulty is mostly fair and provides a decent challenge for those who have the patience to tackle the game.Also, the further the game progresses, the more it starts to feel like a rail shooter - there is little to no wiggle room in terms of routes to take or directions to approach a target from. This makes it feel less like a well-executed action game and more like a brainless shoot-'em-up.While a lot of players couldn't care less for the plot, it should be pointed out that Resident Evil 5 does a terrible job with it. As a standalone story, the plot is unimaginative and sometimes even ridiculous in its clumsy twists, and fails to provide any hooks to keep the player invested in it. It is games like this that encourage cutscene-skipping that reaches out into games that actually could have something relevant to say.But as a sequel to a number of games with good stories, Resident Evil 5 is an absolute butcher. It appears the writers were so in hurry with burying the "previous" generation of the series that they entirely neglected making the story believable, interesting or even in keeping with its predecessors. Returning characters don't feel like the same characters at all, unresolved plot points are omitted without explanation, and existing story details are altered in a way that makes it seem like the writers didn't even know the existing story to begin with. It's one thing to start fresh and deviate from the series' style or themes, but to steamroll over the mythology that fans of the series have been interested in and fallen in love with, that's just being an indifferent jerk.To sum it up, in certain doses, Resident Evil 5 can be adequate fun to pass the time. But it's not an especially good game. And it's definitely not something I'd recommend to anyone who yearns the experiences they had with the classic titles of the series, but obviously, that's a given. So as a Resident Evil game, it's terrible, and as a standalone title, it's nothing special.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												I only recommend this if you're a diehard Resident Evil fan, or just really like on-rails adventure/shooters. Overall I rate it a 2.5 out of 5. It looks a lot nicer, and the controls are a bit better on PC than RE4 (mouselook and strafing, no more tank controls, yay!). But that's about all I can say. Playing this right after beating RE4 makes me a kinda sad. This is a game trying to be a movie or movie trying to be a game. Too many quicktime events and over-scripted "boss fights." Very limited inventory, where an herb and a rocket launcher take up the same space. Buying/selling/upgrading is now relegated to a non-diegetic menu between game "stages." You can also restart stages but keep stuff you picked up, allowing you to farm stuff apparently (I noticed this accidentally when I restarted after a screw up). While RE4 had stages technically, it was a much more seamless experience, you only really knew there were different stages because of the save/load screen. Even the interface for selling treasures is a chore. Also it crashed on me a lot (about ten times give or take, in ~16 hours of play), no idea why - maybe because it uses Games for Windows Live? This almost always happened while in the inventory screen between stages though it happened once shortly after launching the game (around the time it checks GfWL account). In any case I don't think it ever occurred during game play, so I never lost real progress - I just had to sell treasures and upgrade weapons again.

Afterall, killing zombies is a past time activity for me.Resident Evil 5 has a pretty decent campagin, the stroy is not terrible, but of course you can expect Albert Wesker to cause to some trouble again. I played mostly online, but recently went back and didn't find anyone else on. I dont think i would have played this game solo.However, with a friend it can be fun unloading your pistol into some third world zombies.There is a good selection of weapons.Melee combat is satisfyingCamera angles suck, but i enjoy that w/ RE games, whats new?graphics are fine.There is a survival mode where you can partner up and try to get on the leaderboards (good luck)I don't have anything bad to say about this game, other than it might not be as fun in single playerI will say however the RE series was never as good as when they first came out, but no multiplayer :(If you're looking for a single player experiance, look into the remake of RE 1 (where you are in the mansion) That game scares the crap out of me.Else for a multiplayer experiance get this game.8/10

Posted: August 31, 2015
												After a 6 year wait, Resident Evil 5 is finally moved from Microsoft's rubbish & now defunct Games for Windows service, to the Steam platform offering at long last the Gold Edition  ' Untold Stories ' DLC for PC. Resident Evil 5 now gives you additional modes of play via the Mercenaries Reunion mini game along with 2 extra chapters, Lost In Nightmares & Desperate Escape. As usual, better weapons, costumes & other content is unlocked the more you play. Capcom have well and truely abandoned it's Survival Horror roots here, delivering instead a faster paced & more action packed game. Despite it's age & increasingly daft storyline toward the end, Resident Evil 5 delivers a slick enjoyable addition to the series. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												Similar in style to RE4, but improved in some ways and gotten worse in others.Unlike the early games it's not even pretending to be a survival horror, theres no talk of escape, you're charging in big damn heros style wasting everything that gets in your way, and to illustrate that, Chris now has triceps bigger than his ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ legs. There are still a few holdouts from the survival days that don't quite work in an action game though. Not being able to run and gun is one, as is the limited inventory space, having to combine things. There are no puzzles solved by combining. There is no reason why a red and green herb should not auto combine anymore, that is literally the one thing besides choosing grenades for your launcher where you even need the option. Auto pickup for money would be nice too, as there is absolutely no reason why you would ever not grab it.The story and dialogue is still wonderfully corny and stupid, without being completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like in RE4. I wish they'd just play the cutscenes though, instead of making you watch it twice because half of them are bloody QTEs for reasons I'll never really understand. If you're not giving me any agency or options don't punish me for taking my fingers off the keyboard, it's just press a button to get to the end of the scene. It's still mostly good fun though, exploring creepy Africa with your idiot savant partner. Absolutely brilliant with a rifle but mentally disabled when it comes to anything else, which is a pity as all the boss fights are now puzzles which require you to work together in some specific way to beat. "We have to split up to beat it" she says, "one of us will distract it while the other gets behind and shoots it in it's vunerable yellow glowing♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; she says, whilst never moving more than 2 foot away from you. She won't cover you while you use the special weapon that kills the boss, and she'll randomly drop the special weapon to pick flowers when you finally get it pinned.It'd have a great atmosphere if it wasn't for the glowing pickups and disappearing bodies, DOOM got this right straight away and everything since has ♥♥♥♥ed it up. Made you get involved keeping an eye out for valuable ammo, and it felt like walking through a hellish charnel house. In this you know every body lying on the floor will probably get up and do something because everything that's proper dead melts.At least they got rid of the stupid merchant.3 stars, 4 if you play with a friend instead of the AI.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												I remember playing the very fist Resident Evil for Playstation when I was barely 5 years old (and being very scared!).11 years later, this game was the first I had played of the franchise since the the first one all those years ago. I had it on 360 before getting it on Steam.I know a lot of people would argue that this game is not the best of the franchise, but my point is it got me back in to playing Resident Evil, as I developed an interest in the characters and story, and wanted to play all the other games before this one (4 was great, though I think I'd honestly stick to the original Resident Evil and the HD remake, which I also have on here)One thing I love about this title and the other RE games with it, is the vast amount of replay value you get on them.Finishing the story is one challenge, trying to beat it in a certain amount of time is another. Unlocking infinite ammo gives you an edge over your playing speed, and there aren't many other things out there that can give me a buzz as much as blasting my way through groups of enemies.What's more, I am very grateful to Capcom for bringing the Gold Edition content to the PC version, I had been waiting for this for a while and now it's finally here! Thank you, Capcom!!p.s. I look forward to RE Zero coming to Steam early next year, it's a must have in my Games Library!

content:
Posted: December 23, 2011
												This may very well be my most played game of the last five years. I'm a big Resident Evil fan, and finally being able to play a Resident Evil game in co-op with a friend is great. There's a couple of annoying chapters (the on-rails shooting part specifically), but overall this is a solid third person shooter. Wesker is just as awesome a character as he's ever been, and it's a decent ending to a rather silly storyline. That's what makes it so enjoyable though - the sense that Capcom are intentionally being ironically camp with their storylines.Gameplay wise, again, it's a solid shooter, there's a great selection of weaponry, and it's a blast in co-op. Mercenaries mode on PC gets an upgrade too, with "No Mercy" - a mode that spawns a LOT more enemies than the standard version. Great replay value all around. Buy it now if you're yet to experience it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 14, 2012
												A lot different from Resident Evil 4, and definitely not as awesome in all regards, but it's still a great game in its own right. Resident Evil 5 offers fast pace, third-person shooting action, only this time with a co-op partner! Your AI partner can be kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at times, but it's nothing too huge. Their auto-aim (when they decide to make good use of it) can be quite an asset sometimes, heh. Still, the game feels best when played with two people, and trust me, it is a blast! I really don't see why people hate on this game so much; I personally love it. It's got a solid story, fun gameplay, great music (though a bit unfitting for the series, it still works in the game. Hey, the producer was the same guy who made God Hand, so I say let him have his fun XD). All the extra bits (costumes, weapons, filters) are hilarious and can also be good fun to play around with. All in all, a pretty solid game. And hey, if anything else, I'm sure you could easily find a copy in a rental store :3

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												There's something grudgingly admirable about Capcom's determination to make Resident Evil games feel like no other. And yet - even as a long-term fan - when you first pick up Resident Evil 5 it's almost impossible not to find yourself ♥♥♥♥♥ing about the way you can't move and fire. Or the glacial turning speed. Or the unwieldy inventory system. Just like you did with Resident Evil 4, in fact - and Resident Evil Zero before it, and all the others. It comes with the territory. These fundamental design decisions are illogical in a modern context, and part of me wishes Capcom would wake up to the present.But the tradition of survival horror games has its place too. Make it tense. Place just enough ammo and health. Make it a struggle to get by. To enjoy them, you have to be prepared to put to one side the default annoyances. Once you adapt to the way this game plays compared to all the other third-person action-adventures out there, it all rather clicks into place. Perhaps the question to consider from the outset is whether you really want Resident Evil to feel like every other action game or not? Because if the answer's no, then you're halfway to getting the most out of it.In many respects, Resident Evil 5 is content to follow the path of its much-loved predecessor and tweak a few things along the way. It's still very much a series of abrasive set-pieces strung together by camp hilarity. The main addition is the presence of a fully-controllable camera for the first time. Assigned to the right stick, you finally have the option to sweep the viewpoint around as you wish, and as a result the game is more fluid. Although four control configurations are available, the default works just fine, with a squeeze of the left trigger zooming the camera to the trademark over-the-shoulder view (which so many games aped in the wake of Resi 4, remember). The laser pointer remains, and a customisable level of sensitivity allows you to tweak to your own satisfaction.Possibly the most jarring initial impression is how little has changed in the core game mechanics. While the prospect of split-screen or co-op online play tantalises, there's an inescapable feeling of deja vu and frustration as you play with an AI partner. To all intents and purposes, this looks and feels like a reskinned, high-def Resi 4, and what was hugely impressive back then often struggles to repeat the trick this far down the line.Capcom does love a bit of tentacle action.As you'll probably know from the numerous previews, the game kicks off with returning former STARS hero Chris Redfield (from the original 1996 Resident Evil) meeting up with local BSAA operative Sheva Alomar in a dusty African shantytown. Tipped off about a bioterrorist named Irving, it quickly becomes apparent that the hostile natives' attitude problem has more to do with viral shenanigans than a distaste for foreigners. As they are called to arms by a megaphone-wielding leader, Chris and Sheva find themselves running the gauntlet from a feral mob, forced to scale buildings, hop between rooftops and shoot fuel barrels in a desperate fight for survival, occasionally splitting up using co-op moves like the assist jump and then covering one another.The setting might have changed a little, but everything else is inescapably reminiscent of the village sequence of the previous game, right down to the chainsaw-wielding giant, and the need to scale buildings to get some distance from the onslaught. Even the lurching enemies with their side-stepping attack evasion are the same. The weapons they wield are largely identical, as is their physics-defying animation, where foes reel back in familiar exaggerated fashion. From sound effects to graphical style to core gameplay and AI, there has been little or no change apart from an admittedly arresting visual upgrade. It's a different setting, with different character models, but the game you're playing has, for the most part, essentially the exact same template repeated in a different setting. Interesting that his axe doubles up as a storage device. Do you think he's going on holiday?And if that doesn't strike you as mildly disappointing, then the almost complete absence of puzzles and exploration may come as a hammer blow. Where puzzles do exist, they're so crushingly basic as to be insulting, rarely amounting to more than simple, pointless object hunts that take place right next to their intended target. Far from the promised return to the adventurous exploration of old, you simply work your way through six extremely linear chapters where straying off the obvious beaten track is not an option. In addition, the presence of a new mini-map allows you to see exactly where you should be heading if there's any lingering doubt. The dumbing-down of almost every aspect of the gameplay is depressing, if not unexpected. There are even turret gun sections.With so much of the gameplay distilled to a sequence of set-pieces, a significant part of what made Resident Evil appealing has been removed, and what remains is the shooting portion. Pushed front and centre, it morphs what was a survival horror adventure into a survival horror shooter, and many will find Capcom's transparent desire to appeal to the action gaming audience a little troubling. Whereas Resi 4 skillfully straddled a happy middle ground between old and new, Resi 5 embraces the action element without concession. Whether it goes too far, of course, will be a matter of serious discourse.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												Blatent, unmarked spoilers, ahoy~ "I should have killed you years ago, Chris." -WeskerI played through the game wth a friend of mine (so there won't be much comment about the single player experience), as our lovely friend Chris, and was attacked by every living thing in Africa, including Wesker. Enemies would completely ignore Sheva's exsistence to go after Chris, as if it wasn't bad enough that Jill had fallen off-screen during a flashback. Thus, masterfully the atmosphere of the game: The lone American male, partnered up with an African lady in a business suit with the power to make herself invisible to all enemies, going through the adventure of a lifetime. This is his story...See, Chris is in Africa following a lead on a very hazardous weapon... a biohazardous weapon! As well as looking for the reasons of his existence. But, because he's American, the African natives don't like him very much, so the B.S.A.A. sent Sheva to help him out, and protect him from the spookies. Wesker has made his base of opperations here, to unleash Uroborous, the biohazard that will spread across the world, but not if our hero Chris has anything to say about it! There were so many wonderful enemies that Chris has to take on! Giant flying caterpillars with a soft heart, grasshoppers that force themselves on him (and give him the ride of his life), tribals with bathrobes on their faces, black blobs that inhale gas tanks, the giants from Skyrim with textures exclusive to RE5, and many more, including my personal favourite, boulders!Chris is built like a tank, so it only makes sense that he plays like a tank, right? Well, that's why the tank controls have returned, yet again! If you've lived through the Ashley Experience back in 2005, you will feel right at home, because Chris, being bigger, tank-ier, and wanted by every living thing in Africa, plays just like Leon! Sheva is a lefty, so the targeting is on the opposite side, but not that it matters because if you play as Sheva, enemies will ignore you! And, true to the original Biohazard, Chris' inventory is incredibly tiny, just like the good ol' days~! You have 9 slots, and have to make the best of it, because ammo and weapons are abundant, and you will have to make the heartbreaking decision of whether or not Chris will carry the team, and hold the line from every beast, critter, native, and Wesker, or if you want Sheva to work her business outfit. On a slightly more serious note, the game flows, dare I say, perfectly, as Sheva takes all of Chris' demands with little to no delay, at least, when you're playing with a friend. This adventure is very clearly meant for two people to go through it together, and it's a seamless experience. That being said, playing by myself felt like, every time you had to tell Sheva to do something, the pace would slow down to a crawl, until it was finished. I've only played by myself once, so I don't have too much experience on that, but it's evident to me that it's very clearly meant to be played with two real, thinking people. Y'know, like Chris. So, what if you don't want to fight boulders? Well, that's fine, because there are also extra scenarios like The Mercenaries, where you play as Chris, and kill things, or you play as Wesker and kill things, or you play as everyone else, and kill things, on numerous stages, and you can use fire grenades! Big advocate of fire. There's also a scenario where you can play as Chris (and Jill) and play through the flashback explaining what happened to Jill and Chris. There are weapons to unlock, costumes, and you can even toggle infinite ammo, and use that in the story mode. But, play it with a friend, make sure you play as Chris.

Posted: August 22, 2015
												I remember playing the very fist Resident Evil for Playstation when I was barely 5 years old (and being very scared!).11 years later, this game was the first I had played of the franchise since the the first one all those years ago. I had it on 360 before getting it on Steam.I know a lot of people would argue that this game is not the best of the franchise, but my point is it got me back in to playing Resident Evil, as I developed an interest in the characters and story, and wanted to play all the other games before this one (4 was great, though I think I'd honestly stick to the original Resident Evil and the HD remake, which I also have on here)One thing I love about this title and the other RE games with it, is the vast amount of replay value you get on them.Finishing the story is one challenge, trying to beat it in a certain amount of time is another. Unlocking infinite ammo gives you an edge over your playing speed, and there aren't many other things out there that can give me a buzz as much as blasting my way through groups of enemies.What's more, I am very grateful to Capcom for bringing the Gold Edition content to the PC version, I had been waiting for this for a while and now it's finally here! Thank you, Capcom!!p.s. I look forward to RE Zero coming to Steam early next year, it's a must have in my Games Library!

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Following Resident Evil 4 was never going to be easy, and we would argue that Resident Evil 5 waited too long to capitalise on the goodwill generated by its beloved predecessor.The game setting is not that eerie as in previous titles, but for the sake of the story it fit in. Though now we have some Hollywood action packed moments (IE. Zombies riding Dirtbikes), the game still keeps keen on the "somewhat" mindless mutated.Resident Evil 5 is a decent game, providing quite a few hours of gameplay. Though some features were changed for the worst. For example the Inventory system, It was no longer the Resident Evil 4 Tetris Inventory, now it was just a  small 6 pack slot bag, which was quite frustrating as you would struggle to hold items with only 6 spaces, I personally found my self missing out on herbs alot for I didn't have enough bag space.You now have a partner in Resident Evil 5, though she can get quite frustrating at times with her lake of help and just being a poor written AI.As for "Mercenaries mode" it is quite boring for my personal liking, I enjoyed it more in RE 4.Overall the story is okay, the gameplay in story is quite fun and thats where you will spend most of your time.

												Good game, but if you plan to play with a friend keep in mind that:-The second player plays as Sheva, this might be good or not depend on how you feel about her being left handed and her camera angle. In my case, while I eventually got used to it, I experience rates of about 15% better accuracy (end of lvl stats) when playing with Chris just because of the camera angle.-The save system is pretty bad for the 2nd player, if you leave mid chapter it WONT save unless you restart the whole chapter, making you miss unlockables and purchase points.-The save system is also inconsistent, by the time I finished my game I had some chapters completed, some graded but unable to play, some I could play but there was no score whatsoever and so on.-Last mission first checkpoint always dcs the 2nd player and because the checkpoints NEVER get saved for 2nd player if you get invited again you have to start the whole thing (thankfully its close to the start of the chapter(read above why))-Las mission requires a quicktime event for the 2nd player that was literally impossible for me to complete until I decided to switch to a controller for it, if you don't have a controller I suggest avoiding the whole game or getting a friend that has one because of that single quicktime.Would only recommend if it was treated as the 6 year old game it is instead of being overpriced. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												(TL:DR at the bottom)So I'm writing this review with very little game time ON STEAM, most of my hours rest on xbox a while back but am writing a review now since I've just bought the game so am able to.Resident evil 5 is an action game developed by capcom and released in 2009 and very much sticks to less of a horror feel and embraces its' action side.The game is clearly MORE intended to be played with a friend as the A.I. can genuinely be terrible, if playing solo it isn't the WORST A.I. around, but there definitely will be times where it costs you a herb, first aid spray or even a death but that being said, the co-op in this game really IS fun, that's where alot of the games appeal comes into it for me, it's genuinely enjoyable.Now Resident evil 5 is NOT the best game around, it does lack alot and later in the game really begins to feel slow and repetitive, but past that the games definitely something worth trying atleast once for the experience. Voice acting is, as always, not great, and has led me to even the point of laughter on various occasions, but that's quite honestly something I've just come to expect of capcom at this point.Gameplay wise the game is perfectly fine, it has the resi-standard stop to shoot mechanic which can lead to some surprises when getting railed from behind by an angry man with a pipe, and feels pretty fluent down to the inventory which is very easy to use, by the end of the game there is a huge variety of guns, then upgradable with the money you get from selling various treasures found when playing through, and with some upgraded guns leading to the unlock of OTHER guns, the game is definitely not short of reasons to replay, from BSAA emblems to mercenaries mode or (like myself) just wanting the satisfaction of having every gun in the game fully upgraded, resident evil 5 leaves you with SO much to do even beyond your first completion unlike many other games where once complete, they just lack replayability. TL:DR- Resident evil 5 is a very fun game best played with a friend but not at all unplayable solo. It holds a ton of replay value and even including the slow feeling of the late game, the quite honestly hilarious voice acting (not a good thing) and the dodgy A.I. I'd definitely say this game is worth a try! :)Hope this review came in handy, I'm not the most experience review writer around what with this being like my 2nd one, but criticism is always accepted!

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												In a way I'm conflicted: I thoroughly enjoyed Resident Evils 1-4, even though the first zombie in the original Resident Evil gave me nightmares at the age of roughly 8. You can say I have a hate/hate relationship with Resident Evil in general, however overcoming and defeating the game and the monsters within always came with a measure of satisfaction.We've move pretty fast in a short amount of time: going from the glorious blocky-ness of older RE games to even refurbishing and re-releasing them as of the time of writing this review (I can't wait to see RE2 and 3 come out remastered) however we've gone away from being a Survival-Horror game with a bit of inventory management and we've moved to full blown, over-the-top Action-Shooter territory. No longer are you hampered by a scarcity of resources, you can readily re-play stages to horde gold and ammo for your next foray into the story itself. While Resident Evil 4 struck a balance, Resident Evil 5 did away with it quite quickly. Whether this is good or bad really depends on how you approach the game, and how quickly you realize that you should take away that pistol from your AI partner who isn't quite good at it. Give her a Sub Machine Gun, you know you just spray and pray, she'll actually save you ammunition.The most horrifying aspects of the game remain the surprise boss fights against things that will murder you quickly, but with checkpoints and "save areas" in between, you can die, re-kit, and then succeed. It is worth noting that restarting later stages is crucial, as you will often need to change your load out to face a boss or a particular situation.The graphics look nice, but then I never put too much weight on graphics, being the kind of person who thoroughly enjoys playing games like Arcanum and Fallout, and the controls handle well with a 360 Controller, though it still bothers me that the laser reticule doesn't "shine" on walls and only on things you can "hit'.          7.8/10

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												There are certain glitches in the co-op version that my friend and I have discovered via trial and error. For instance, if I join in the middle of my friend's level, and not at the start of the chapter, I cannot upgrade my weapons. In addition, my score is not recorded. So if your friend's internet or yours is a bit wonky, you may want to consider this. As one who's played it on both the xbox and the pc, I'd definitely say this pc version has better grafix -- you can see more, enjoy more, and be more annoyed when the quick time events pop up out of nowhere. Fun game, exciting, and great for cooperative play. I'd rank it as the best cooperative game to date, because it requires participation and camaraderie, and you really get attached to your partner. :) It's a lot of fun! Despite its cheesy story and endearingly awkward mechanics, I definitely recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
												Even though this installment may not include any spooky horror stuff, it's still a great entry in my book. First of all, this game stars Chris Redfield, who is more of an action hero than, say, Leon from the previous Resident Evil, who is more into scary stuff. The zombies in this game are like your regular everyday dead guys, similar in a way to Left 4 Dead's, only that they don't sprint that much, and they can shoot arrows and throw grenades (smart guys!). There are a few exceptions which may throw you off the first time yoy play, but nothing too hard really.Second of all, it has great replayablity, especially if you play with a friend. There are many QTE moments that will either hurt your hand or make you feel a sense of accomplishment when completed (again, this is on the first playthrough).The biggest con for this game is the AI partner. End of story. It's so bad, so don't ever give it a gun, unless you played the game a couple of times and can afford infinite ammo for it, then it gets better.That should be it. My recommendation, get a friend, get 2 copies of RE5 and play on. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												Intense moment-to-moment action, designed for in-a-pinch improvisational tactics and recovery.Great environments spanning multiple levels with different themes and feels; the whole campaign feels thematically diverse and never becomes stale as it cycles through multiple environments often.Decent story; disregards the tone of previous Resident Evil games for the most part and that may not please everybody, but it retains its beautiful saturday afternoon action movie feel without ruining the overall lore of the series.Good replayability, decent extras with Mercenaries and the DLC, albeit priced slightly unfairly for its age, provides a decent degree of new content to explore.Wonderfully scalable engine, allows for good performance on a lot of different machines. Plays perfectly at 60fps and 1080p on my midend laptop.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												Edit: Grab it in the humble bundle cheap. Also the GFWL is for importing your stats. No idea what everyone is on about needing community tweaks to bypass it. It asked me if I wanted install GFWL on 1st run. I said no. Game crashed. I reran and it ran fine with no GFWL bs.Kudos to Capcom for patching the game recently. It could be argued that it should have been patched ages ago but that applies to every major publisher & lack of support after dlcs have been released. At least they got to it eventually instead of pretending the game doesn't exist (I'm looking at you Activision).As for the game, it is brilliant. I've played through it half dozen times on the x360 & then once on the pc. The atmospehere & level design is amazing on most of the levels. It is nothing like the first 4 REs & gets a lot of hate as a result. Personally Ive never been a fan of relying on blind spots created by fixed camera angles to create shock (project zero is a perfect example). The AI has improved over the x360s useless version but the game wont be as fun without that coop. I first time I played I hated I couldn't move+shoot, the limited inventory & the laser sight (I was a fps shooter fan). These factors are actually great in hindsight. Inability to run & gun adds to the atmosphere. The inventory space means you can't tomb raider it & must choose which weapons you want to bring into the level. This also means if you bring more than 4 weapons you wont be able to carry all the ammo types for them (once armor, heals etc are carried). This ammo management replaces the scarceness of ammo in the early games. The laser sight works better than a crosshair for 3rd person accuracy.Verdict: When it goes on sale grab 2 copies & play through it with a friend. The only network lag I faced was 1sec pauses in a couple of cutscences.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												People say that this game doesn't follow original trilogy in terms of gameplay. They're wrong. Bulky controls, check (actually I like 'tank controls); camera that will always hide enemies from you, check; slow melee enemies that will always outrun your bullets, check. Extremally low fov prevent you to see enemies attacking from sides when going/shooting forward. If you see something on your side it's already too late. Low fov and turn speed that (actually) has two gears 'you will never tour if you don't throw your mouse like stone in curling' and 'you will spin like Tasmanian Devil from Looney Tunes', are main think that prevents you from jumping to Mercenaries mode for two games after week of playing different games. You need to 'learn' RE5 gameplay every time when you go back after break.Still it has one of best two player coop campaings ever made. Also coop Mercenaries (and if you have Gold Edtion - Mercenaries Reunion).

Product received for free
												Resident Evil 5 has both good and bad parts to the game. The good parts is the storyline and the time taken with the details in the game and the action sequences such as the boss fights which makes the game challenging and fun to play. However the bad parts of the game are the camera handle when playing co-op is horrible and reminds me of playing on a playstation 2 title. However this has been changed in the latest game of the series which is a big improvement. I would recommend this game to players who follow the series as I only played the game with a friend who wanted me to play co-op. But it is a fun game to play and worth buying for the price.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												Of the RE Pack PC Port, RE5 is done the best (8/10)Disclaimer: I tweaked the single player campaign experience for PC. Having played the PS3 version previously I wanted to get past things I have already done. I have no interest in multiplayerControls: Keyboard turning was done away, unlike RE4 (hurrah for mouse look and aiming!)1-9 item slot key bind was done well (no complaints).Strafing would be nice, but I'd think that would be too much to ask for from a console port.Inventory management is dumbed down but...For a console port action game, I don't think it can get better.Grab 1 or 2 weapons, ammunition, armor, and healing items.Inventory tetris from RE4 is mixed bag for me, I don't hate it, but it is very time consuming.Visual: Apparently this is all DX9, I can't say I expected anything more superior because I understood this as a console port in the first place.Game play: Cut scene actions are still annoying, but seems incredibly well done after going through RE6.I would not say the game can be classified as a survival horror, but RE5 is a very well done action game.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												Has a bad rep for being more combat-shooter than previous RE games. There is clear focus on the third person shooting, stagger into mele-combo punish, a couple of turret sections and fairly strict level linearity, but at least the "tank controls" were replaced by something functional, the visuals fit well with the franchise and the hub inventory system made collecting different (upgradeable) weapons an interesting side-hobby for me as I played.If you can handle the action/co-op style focus then the usual resident evil plot sillyness is there and I personally found the chaptering of the game to be well done, it allowed for an unusually consistent plot pace and provided some replay value to more interesting areas (or to collect hidden items/farm some upgrade funds).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												(TL:DR at the bottom)So I'm writing this review with very little game time ON STEAM, most of my hours rest on xbox a while back but am writing a review now since I've just bought the game so am able to.Resident evil 5 is an action game developed by capcom and released in 2009 and very much sticks to less of a horror feel and embraces its' action side.The game is clearly MORE intended to be played with a friend as the A.I. can genuinely be terrible, if playing solo it isn't the WORST A.I. around, but there definitely will be times where it costs you a herb, first aid spray or even a death but that being said, the co-op in this game really IS fun, that's where alot of the games appeal comes into it for me, it's genuinely enjoyable.Now Resident evil 5 is NOT the best game around, it does lack alot and later in the game really begins to feel slow and repetitive, but past that the games definitely something worth trying atleast once for the experience. Voice acting is, as always, not great, and has led me to even the point of laughter on various occasions, but that's quite honestly something I've just come to expect of capcom at this point.Gameplay wise the game is perfectly fine, it has the resi-standard stop to shoot mechanic which can lead to some surprises when getting railed from behind by an angry man with a pipe, and feels pretty fluent down to the inventory which is very easy to use, by the end of the game there is a huge variety of guns, then upgradable with the money you get from selling various treasures found when playing through, and with some upgraded guns leading to the unlock of OTHER guns, the game is definitely not short of reasons to replay, from BSAA emblems to mercenaries mode or (like myself) just wanting the satisfaction of having every gun in the game fully upgraded, resident evil 5 leaves you with SO much to do even beyond your first completion unlike many other games where once complete, they just lack replayability. TL:DR- Resident evil 5 is a very fun game best played with a friend but not at all unplayable solo. It holds a ton of replay value and even including the slow feeling of the late game, the quite honestly hilarious voice acting (not a good thing) and the dodgy A.I. I'd definitely say this game is worth a try! :)Hope this review came in handy, I'm not the most experience review writer around what with this being like my 2nd one, but criticism is always accepted!

												Although I choose to recommend this game, it actually has so many bugs. First, you can exchange weapon with the NPC , that's so awful. Second, some enemy that has some vital items will never show up. For example, in the Tanker chapter, you will need a Key card to unlock the door to the crane control panel or you can't save the teammate trapped in the cargo cage, but the enemy that has the key card will be stuck and never shows up. This makes me unable to finish the game, and Capcom still doesn't have the patch for these bugs. So I suggest those who want this game in your library should wait for a while . Don't buy this game until all the bugs are fixed.

												This was the first Resident Evil game I'd ever played. A friend gifted it to me simply for the co-op. I'd happily play this again. At some point, I do plan on playing the others.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												Similar in style to RE4, but improved in some ways and gotten worse in others.Unlike the early games it's not even pretending to be a survival horror, theres no talk of escape, you're charging in big damn heros style wasting everything that gets in your way, and to illustrate that, Chris now has triceps bigger than his ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ legs. There are still a few holdouts from the survival days that don't quite work in an action game though. Not being able to run and gun is one, as is the limited inventory space, having to combine things. There are no puzzles solved by combining. There is no reason why a red and green herb should not auto combine anymore, that is literally the one thing besides choosing grenades for your launcher where you even need the option. Auto pickup for money would be nice too, as there is absolutely no reason why you would ever not grab it.The story and dialogue is still wonderfully corny and stupid, without being completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like in RE4. I wish they'd just play the cutscenes though, instead of making you watch it twice because half of them are bloody QTEs for reasons I'll never really understand. If you're not giving me any agency or options don't punish me for taking my fingers off the keyboard, it's just press a button to get to the end of the scene. It's still mostly good fun though, exploring creepy Africa with your idiot savant partner. Absolutely brilliant with a rifle but mentally disabled when it comes to anything else, which is a pity as all the boss fights are now puzzles which require you to work together in some specific way to beat. "We have to split up to beat it" she says, "one of us will distract it while the other gets behind and shoots it in it's vunerable yellow glowing♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; she says, whilst never moving more than 2 foot away from you. She won't cover you while you use the special weapon that kills the boss, and she'll randomly drop the special weapon to pick flowers when you finally get it pinned.It'd have a great atmosphere if it wasn't for the glowing pickups and disappearing bodies, DOOM got this right straight away and everything since has ♥♥♥♥ed it up. Made you get involved keeping an eye out for valuable ammo, and it felt like walking through a hellish charnel house. In this you know every body lying on the floor will probably get up and do something because everything that's proper dead melts.At least they got rid of the stupid merchant.3 stars, 4 if you play with a friend instead of the AI.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2011
												While not living up to the greatness that is RE4 (widely considered to be one of the best games of all time), this is a great addition to the RE franchise. It isn't scary (but IMO RE4 wasn't either) but is is very tense due to teh returning stop-and-shoot gameplay. The graphics are some of this best out there and the game runs smooth as butter. Plenty of hours here. Biggest negative, and it is a huge one, is that the co-op is required. Even if there is no human player, the 2nd player is AI controlled. This is the worst thing that could happen to a "horror" game. Completly ruins the sense of being alone which is generally where the fear/intensity comes from. Get it for $10-$15, maybe $20.

												Of the RE Pack PC Port, RE5 is done the best (8/10)Disclaimer: I tweaked the single player campaign experience for PC. Having played the PS3 version previously I wanted to get past things I have already done. I have no interest in multiplayerControls: Keyboard turning was done away, unlike RE4 (hurrah for mouse look and aiming!)1-9 item slot key bind was done well (no complaints).Strafing would be nice, but I'd think that would be too much to ask for from a console port.Inventory management is dumbed down but...For a console port action game, I don't think it can get better.Grab 1 or 2 weapons, ammunition, armor, and healing items.Inventory tetris from RE4 is mixed bag for me, I don't hate it, but it is very time consuming.Visual: Apparently this is all DX9, I can't say I expected anything more superior because I understood this as a console port in the first place.Game play: Cut scene actions are still annoying, but seems incredibly well done after going through RE6.I would not say the game can be classified as a survival horror, but RE5 is a very well done action game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												This game has aged beautifully. Graphically it's still better than any Resident Evil game to come after it. The serious tone of the game is tastefully done while still mainting an all out action movie feel like RE4. While not as epic and grand in scope as RE4, this game's story resinated more with me due in fact to the good story that is tied into the Resident Evil universe(unlike RE4 which was it's own thing). I thought Chris's character was very well written and he came off as a real level headed bad♥♥♥♥♥ The gameplay was exactly like RE4 so of course it's awesome. The cutscenes were very well done, it felt like you were watching a movie most of the time. The length of the game was a cupple hours shorter than RE4 but who really cares? The Co-op aspect of this game is absolutely incredible and shouldn't be missed by anyone that enjoys playing games with a friend. Now that this game is a few years old(6 to be exact) , it's starting to gain a little steam and be more well received by gamers and Resident Evil fans alike. This is largely due too the recent batch of RE games that have yet to surpass this game in any real aspects from graphics, story, gameplay, level design, etc. Aside from Resident Evil HD Remaster, but that doesn't count:)9/10 Awesome Game

												What can I say I HATE GFWL. The cutscenes break up the action, the QTE's are brutal and the control sceheme is nothing like it was in RE4. RE4 had a 180 button, 360 controller on pc, nope. there's space for it too. I will say capcoms controller usage is nice and works well. it makes a PC port feel less of a port and more of a console title. The action was plenty but the key elements from RE are missing. very few puzzles. and the ones there were there were tedious and lacked imagination. the bosses were big, but also lacked imagination, using markers to signal weak points etc. its a very capcom title, sad to see it not a RE title though. 7.0/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												Resident Evil 5 is a great game.  I think it get's heavily shafted as a poor follow up to one of the greatest games of all time, that being Resident Evil 4 obviously.  Sure, it is not as good as the latter, but it is still a damn fine game.  This is the first Resident Evil that went for heavy action as a scare tactic, and it did it very well.  There were plenty of moments where the shear amount of things going on at once kept me on the edge of my seat, and christ, this game is 5 years old and it is still gorgeous.  I mean really, really gorgeous, and the music is even more beautiful!  It's hard to believe this is a last-gen game.  Now for the things that kept this game from being amazing:  The AI is horrendous and makes single-player play a bad level of challenging, and even worse, you STILL control like a tank, but I guess that's one of the things that's still classic Resident Evil.  I also vaguely remember playing this game with a friend on one TV at one point, and I yearned to stop.  There were also some moments where the development screamed "make it more like Gears of War", and I don't want that in Resident Evil.  Let's face it, there's little to no originality in that series, and that impeeded the development of this game for sure.  In spite of those problems, I've had the will to play through this game multiple times.  It was a lot of fun, definitely worth the money despite some flaws.  There is no DLC for the PC version as it didn't sell well enough, which is a shame because "Lost In Nightmares" was so much fun, and I had a lot more fun playing this on PC than I did on a console.  Oh, and of course, the game is not racist.  Come on.
